questions.question_text: There are multiple options of migrating Oracle Databases from on-premises to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. Which two characteristics do you need to consider when choosing a migration method? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: B, C. This question was in Oracle Practice exam.
A looks like it could be right - but it mentions the application version which is not relevant, so that leaves B and C
B and c
BC is the correct answer

Some of the characteristics and factors to consider when choosing a migration method are:

On-premises database version
Database service database version
On-premises host operating system and version
On-premises database character set
Quantity of data, including indexes
Data types used in the on-premises database
Storage for data staging
Acceptable length of system outage
Network bandwidth

choices.B: On-premises database version and quantity of data, including indexes
choices.C: On-premises host operating system platform and network bandwidth
choices.A: On-premises database character set and application version
choices.D: On-premises connectivity using remote and local VCN peering

discussion.content: ABCEF is correct
ABCEF is correct
I also agree on ABCEF
Answer is ABCEF. Host name is optional, and by default you are assigned a Private IP.

questions.question_text: Which five are the required parameters to launch an instance in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure? (Choose five)

discussion.content:
Agree with A.

Better still, bring it back on-prem. Had it been on VMware, all you'd need to do is increase the size of the vmdk and blow up the disk in the OS. <simples> :D

Don't take this too seriously, only a light joke ;)

I know for all comments that correct answer is A, but in this way (A) you don't preserve boot volume so all data in smaller boot volume will be lost like old Logs. If I wanted to preserve the Logs, suddenly will be necessary rsync .

A.
Because the logs are filling the boot space, so logs are foundamental then you need to resolve the issue. Better create another machine for resolve the problem definitively.

To me, none of the option is correct, I can increase the boot volume size on the fly. I just did for one of my instance. However, out of these 4 options provided option "A" is the most relevant & logical one.
D, note boot volume. A makes no sense as you should not have to reconfigure applications etc too much work. Rysnc is a definite no
A is the correct answer!

Correct Answer is A:
https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Block/Tasks/resizingavolume.htm
why not C?

comments.content: I guess anything saying "rsync" is unnecessary.

discussion.content: Correct Answer is A
Even with looking at the discussion, I also thought A seems more logical. From my experience, the best answer would follow all the step by step best practice A seems to do that.
I think it's A, it has no sense rsync block volume, you only need to reattach it and no sense rsync boot volume.

questions.question_text:
Within your tenancy you have a compute instance with a boot volume and a block volume attached. The boot volume contains the OS and the attached block volume contains the instance's important data. Logs on the boot volume have filled the boot volume and are causing issues with the OS.
What should you do to resolve this situation?

choices.B: Create a new instance with a larger boot volume size as well a new block volume which is the same size or larger than the one attached to the full instance. rsync the state of the boot volume and the state of the block volume between the two instances.
choices.A: Stop the instance that is full. Create a manual backup of the block storage before making changes. Detach the block volume, create a new instance of the same shape with a larger custom boot volume and attach the block volume to the new instance. Configure the OS and any related application(s) to access the block volume under the same mount point as before.
choices.C: Detach the block volume from the full instance. Create a new instance of the same shape with a larger boot volume and rsync the state of the boot volume between the instances. Attach the block volume to the new instance.
choices.D: Create a manual backup of the block storage instance. Create a custom image of the full instance. Once that completes deploy the custom image to a new instance.

questions.question_text: Which two resources are available by default when your Oracle Cloud Infrastructure tenancy is provisioned? (Choose two.)

choices.A: an NVMe SSD boot disk for each instance, whose size is determined by the image and shape of the instance
choices.C: a set of images, where each image is a template of a virtual hard drive that consists of the OS and installed software and applications
choices.D: a variety of shapes, where each shape determines the number of CPUs and memory allocated to an instance.
choices.B: a range of public IP addresses that are reserved for your tenancy

discussion.content: Solution is C,D.
C, D is correct answer

Correct Answer: C,D

NVMe boot disks are not available to all shapes, only to VM.DenseIO(x) and VM.DenseIO(x). The other shapes: VM.Standard(x), BM.Standard(x), VM.GPU(x) and BM.GPU(x) have block storage as the only local disk option.
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/References/computeshapes.htm

Certain types of resources in your tenancy are designed to be directly reachable from the internet and therefore automatically come with a public IP address. For example: a NAT gateway or a public load balancer. Other types of resources are directly reachable only if you configure them to be. For example: instances in your VCN.
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Tasks/managingpublicIPs.htm

Platform Images:
An image is a template of a virtual hard drive. The image determines the operating system and other software for an instance.
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/References/images.htm

I think that only D is true the C maybe(an application can be ODI for example).

A,B totally false.

Option C says, " image is a template of a virtual hard drive that consists of the OS and installed software and applications". Does the image consists of "installed software and applications" ? I don't think so.
C & D is the correct answer!
C, D is the correct answer
C and D
C and D
Deffo, CD.

choices.A: Configure a Dynamic Route Gateway in your VCN and make it highly available.
choices.C: Create an Internet Gateway and attach it to your VCN. Deploy public load balancer nodes into two Available Domains.
choices.B: Configure a NAT instance in your Virtual Cloud Network (VCN). Create a route rule by using the private IP of the NAT instance as a route target for all the private subnets in your VCN.
choices.D: Place all web servers behind a public load balancer.

discussion.content:
C. Create an Internet Gateway and attach it to your VCN. Deploy public load balancer nodes into two Available Domains. - FOR HIGH AVAILABILITY.
D. Place all web servers behind a public load balancer. - INTERNET FACING LB SHOULD BE PUBLIC
I believe answer should be c & d
C and d
C, D is the right answer!
C & D Correct
The correct answer is C and D
Correct answer is C & D

Definitely CD.

A is a good idea but only when the question's about routing.
B doesn't make the solution highly available. The single NAT instance is a SPoF.
I totally agree with C&D

questions.question_text:
Your company is moving an Internet-facing, 2-tier web application into Oracle Cloud Infrastructure. The application must have a highly available architecture.
Which two design options would you consider? (Choose two.)
